narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We did a good bit of history, which was refreshing for a philosophy major! It was my first time doing genuine practical ethics: I haven't seen another class at Yale where you get to do this yet. Darwall is great at letting us do real philosophy while always staying close to the actual history. You'll learn about the issue at real depth, and come away with a much more nuanced view than you initially held (I promise!).
I learned about the history and different arguments regarding reparations and abolition.
I developed insights into various reparatory frameworks as well as a deeper knowledge of the history of injustice against Black Americans.

This was one of the most eye-opening courses I have taken at Yale. Professor Darwall is an excellent facilitator and has selected some excellent readings to understand the issue of reparations from multiple standpoints.
In-depth history of reconstruction, Philosophical works on race and social class, philosophical works on ethics and reparations issues

Non-ideal theory about racial injustice and how to repair those harms, evaluated the strengths and drawbacks of various arguments for reparations, in-depth historical readings about various injustices against African-Americans

We learned how to apply often abstract moral philosophy/ethics to a present, ongoing problem: Black reparations in the U.S. By examining both the specific history linked to slavery and its successors in tandem with philosophies of mutual moral obligations, restorative, distributive, and compensatory justice, we thought through arguments for how best address one of Americas most grave moral wounds, socially, politically, and economically.
A philosophical and historical understanding of the foundation of and issues surrounding claims for American Black reparations.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It's well structured, you learn a lot, Darwall is great at managing discussion, and he's a fair grader. Only thing is sometimes we were assigned perhaps an unreasonably high amount of reading, but usually it wasn't too difficult if so.

This course was really strengthened by Professor Darwall and the other students. Discussions were lively and enlightening. I think that the reading load was sometimes intimidating, but Professor Darwall did occasionally adapt it. I might have liked for there to be a word limit on the weekly reading responses because this sometimes felt competitive but not always substantive.
Hard to think of improvements. A wonderful classroom community even with the constraints of being virtual.
I have no critiques of this course. The reading selected were exemplary and showed a great deal of care and consideration on behalf of Professor Darwall in the syllabus.
A comprehensive overview of the history of race relations in the United States and of theories of justice, equality, and reparations.

This course is excellent and I have few comments for how it could be improved. I liked the structure: how we began with foundational theories from Locke and Mills, and moved to historical study before ending on the reparations arguments proposed by various thinkers.

Strengths: meaningful discussions! This class is entirely discussion based and twice a week half the class prepares discussion questions to lead the seminar. Further, diverse readings historically (covering history of American slavery to Jim Crow to mass incarceration) philosophically, (covering Locke to Rawls to Mills; arguments for and against reparations)
Weaknesses: by the nature of the classs philosophically dense material, we didnt get to fully deconstruct and dissect certain important arguments

The course is very strong. Professor Darwall is excellent and the issue is important, interesting, and in a place where we can make meaningful contributions (unlike some more traditional philosophical concepts). The only weakness for me was the amount of reading: I found it to be difficult to keep up with the readings, especially during the history-focused portion of the coursewhile I understand that there is a large amount of information, and that the topic deserves more attention and respect (which may justify a higher reading load), I found it to be prohibitive.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought that the discussion was always fascinating. I might have liked a more random order for discussing student responses as this sometimes led later students' posts to not get enough class time.
Worked as well as a seminar can given the circumstances.
Success- seminar was very interactive, a lot of out of class assignments became hard when on the screen all the time due to virtual learning.

Good professor engagement with students. I appreciate how Prof Darwall checked in with everyone informally at the start of each seminar. It warmed the class atmosphere and reminded us we are in dialogue with each other. Check-ins, frequent back-and-forth seminar discussion, and attentive listening on the part of the professor and students created an intimate seminar environment that mimicked in-person seminars.

The twice-a-week discussion posts meaningfully linked each Zoom session, filling in the space between them with intellectual engagement, and allowed for optimal use of class time, as we went through CANVAS questions/arguments and tackled them one by one.

The added break was very appreciated. The Fall semester was grueling without breaksProfessor Darwall cancelling one class during the middle of the semester was great and helped with my burnout in this and other courses.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: PLEASE TAKE THIS COURSE. not unreasonably difficult grading, intriguing subject, and you get to take it with Darwall! Especially good for EPE majors: it's the only class in the whole major that allows you to actually use normative theorizing and the tools of social science in a robust way. You also feel pretty free to share your genuine opinions and ideas as you see them. Yale classes are almost always overly restrictive in what's an acceptable idea, or they're filled with people who just want to troll and "play devils advocate for a second" to be provocative for no reason. Darwall created an environment where people could speak their minds, but so long as they were genuine about what they thought and why. I've never seen this in another Yale class. Also: you are really encouraged to think for yourself in the papers, which is huge. Not just "react to this or that idea". This has gotta be one of the best seminars yale offers.

I would absolutely recommend this course to other students. Professor Darwall is very kind and thoughtful and put together a fantastic syllabus. He really is able to draw out students' ideas and the material, and the discussion of reparations was very fascinating and relevant.
Absolutely! Allowed for a thorough examination of engaging topics.
Yes, this class is a must-take for me. It was thoughtful, engaging, and challenging.
I 100% recommend this course if you are interested in the practical application of ethics and also enjoy combining historical/empirical with theoretical/philosophical approaches.
Yes- for those seeking an in-depth analysis of a very specific topic
Definitely recommend this course. Prof Darwall is an excellent, attentive, caring seminar leader, and the material transformed my way of thinking about racial injustice.

Absolutely. Not only is reparations a currently extremely salient unresolved issue in America, this class provides the critical tools to understanding our moral obligations from the individual to societal scale, empowering us to tackle justice in a historically situated manner.
Yes, it's a great classan important topic with a great professor, and very accessible to non-philosophy majors!
